messageBody:
So said Lauren Bish on 2/22/2003 --------------------

>----- Original Message -----

>I am not saying that interfaces shouldn't be
>allowed to change, but at some point they should become stable - and
that
>point is usually reached long before an independent unit tester get's
their
>hands on the unit.

It's not immediately apparent to me why this should be, but that
doesn't much matter. You have obviously employed independent unit
testers after this expected point of convergence, which has helped make
this work for you. I'm not sure about generalizing, though. That's just
a matter of opinion -- for each of us.

Some interfaces stabilize, others do not. The ones that tends to
stabilize are the ones at the boundaries between subsystems or
components. Internal interfaces may change daily. At the least,
virtually every new feature changes an interface somewhere.

>> So explain to me the difference between what you describe and Pair
>> Programming combined with TDD. Is it just that other programmers
are,
>> on their own, writing tests for my stuff after I've written it?
>
>There can be. As with all things, team structure, process and
methodology
>can be tweaked to suit the team and the project. As you stated, TDD is
not
>primarily meant to find bugs, whereas independent unit testing is very
good
>at that, and generally that is its primary purpose; early testing. If
you
>have an XP team that is so good that they write perfect code, and a
*good*
>independent unit tester can't find any bugs in the code, then don't
use
>independent unit testers and more power to you. But I have yet to see
such
>a
>team or such developers - and I feel fairly confident that I could
write
>unit tests that would find significant bugs in just about any new
codebase
>under development - including a codebase developed using TDD.

I don't like the idea that they are writing tests on their own. My fear
is that they will make different assumptions about the code's intended
behavior.

By the way, I stated that TDD is not meant to find bugs, period. Delete
"primarily". I conjecture that the reason that many people fight with
Programmer Tests is that they want PTs to find bugs, when that is not
their purpose at all. Again, that is my opinion, but I think it's
right.
